The Difference Between Digital and Linear Audiences
الفرق بين الجماهير الرقمية والخطية
Sometimes a story jumps out at you right away. But most of the time, good stories are waiting for you to find them. Here are some ways to get started:

Linear AudiencesIn general, linear audiences consume the news from a ‘lean back’ position. Once they tune in to a specific TV news broadcast, it is likely they will watch it until the end. They play a relatively passive role in curating their experience, leaving the choice of what news they consume up to the editors of the channel that they have chosen to watch.

الجماهير الخطية بشكل عام، تستهلك الجماهير الخطية الأخبار من موقع «التراجع». بمجرد الاستماع إلى بث إخباري تلفزيوني معين، فمن المحتمل أن يشاهدوه حتى النهاية. إنهم يلعبون دورًا سلبيًا نسبيًا في تنظيم تجربتهم، تاركين اختيار الأخبار التي يستهلكونها لمحرري القناة التي اختاروا مشاهدتها.

Digital AudiencesDigital users are often consuming news in short bursts and at unpredictable times. They make active choices about what news they want to consume and may switch to another news brand, non-news content or a totally different activity on their device at any time. Keeping the attention of digital audiences is a major challenge for digital news outlets.

Once digital news consumers have chosen to read an article or watch a video on your website or app, it’s critically important that they get what they came for. If the content of an article or the footage in a video does not match the expectations of the consumer, they will lose trust in the outlet, making them less likely to come back for more in future.

Expectations
التوقعات

When linear TV audiences tune in to a news broadcast, they trust the editors to serve them the stories that they need to know about. By contrast, digital news consumers curate their own news experience by selecting the stories they want to read about or the videos they want to watch. Digital journalists use headlines and thumbnails to inspire the curiosity of the audience.

Competitive pressure can lead news outlets to present stories in a hysterical or sensational manner. Journalists have to constantly escalate the ‘hype’ factor to win the battle for clicks. Over time, this can lead to a 'dumbing-down' of the news and an emphasis on shock value.

Equating a simple metric such as page views with journalistic impact or success can lead to the ‘tyranny of the majority’. Metrics inevitably under-represent the behaviour of smaller segments of the audience, such as minorities, and this can lead to their interests being marginalised.

Scrollytelling is a kind of narrative visualization that unfolds as a user scrolls down the page.
